text:
One of the most important
things to figure out with AI

is how government can
help play a role with all

of this, and the
progress that we expect
over the next couple of years--

AI makes that, I think,
more important and urgent.

And this seems like an
interesting first step

to get people from industry
talking with people

in government who want to figure
out how to use this technology
and regulate it.

Given the magnitude
of economic change,

at a minimum, how we
think about the evolution

of the social contract, what
that means, how people--

the balance between
capital and labor, just

to pick one obvious example
of many others we could pick--

that's going to require
serious societal debate.

And by the way, this
is the main reason

that I think our strategy
of incremental deployment,

iterative deployment
is so important.

The fact that we put out
systems along the way

rather than go
build for 10 years

and then drop this like
incredible AGI on the world

all at once gives us time
to have those conversations,

debate, get the input,
adapt, all of that.

The shape of jobs will change,
and decades in the future,
who knows?

I think what those jobs look
like may be very different than

what you or I would
consider a "real job" today.

I think policy works best when
it's downstream of the science.

There's all these things
that sound like great policy

ideas in theory, but
if the technology

goes in a super
different way than how

we think it's going to go, you
might need a very different set
of policy tools to do it.

One idea that I find
quite compelling

is something like an IAEA
for advanced AI systems

and say if you have
one of the 10 systems

in the world that is
over this threshold,

you're going to have the
equivalent of weapons

inspectors, and we're going to
focus the international policy

on catastrophic risk
that affects all of us.

Did you have an a-ha
moment when you said, wow,

this is going to be bigger
than I even thought?
I did.

It was when we first discovered
that scaling language
models worked so predictably.

When we started
OpenAI, we kind of

knew that deep
learning seemed to work

and it seemed to get
better with scale.
